diff.*:
Line 18: Line 18:      
Love has several different meanings in the [[English (language)|English]] language, from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something that one would die for ([[patriotism]], [[pair-bonding]]). And in contrast to the definition at the top, frequently people use the verb "love" to indicate want or desire for themselves as opposed to for another. For example: "I love ice cream," or even "I love Fidelia," does not refer to desiring wellness for ice cream, and it may not refer to desiring wellness for her/him, but rather to the desire for ice cream or for her/him felt by the speaker. The word also frequently indicates elevated appreciation or admiration: "I love that artist."
 
Love has several different meanings in the [[English (language)|English]] language, from something that gives a little pleasure ("I loved that meal") to something that one would die for ([[patriotism]], [[pair-bonding]]). And in contrast to the definition at the top, frequently people use the verb "love" to indicate want or desire for themselves as opposed to for another. For example: "I love ice cream," or even "I love Fidelia," does not refer to desiring wellness for ice cream, and it may not refer to desiring wellness for her/him, but rather to the desire for ice cream or for her/him felt by the speaker. The word also frequently indicates elevated appreciation or admiration: "I love that artist."
−   −
I love you Mandi,
  −
You have always been there for me when I've needed you,
  −
I don't deserve you kindness,
  −
I hate myself for putting you through so much,
  −
I understand that our hearts are in 2 different places,
  −
but really, i do love you, whether you love me in return or not.
  −
You are one of the most amazing girls I've known.
  −
You are the most amazing person I've met.
  −
Because of you I feel like a good person.
  −
You make me want to do better,
  −
for myself and for others.
  −
You showed me that I deserve more for myself than what I've done in the past.
  −
With my heart,
  −
Keenan Cameron
  −   −        
Love might best be defined as acting intentionally, in sympathetic response to others to promote overall well-being. Or to put it simply, "love responds intentionally to promote well-being" ([[Thomas Jay Oord]]). Love promotes overall flourishing, but often focuses on those close at hand.
